You should then clean up any state and exit your app. The updater will apply updates and then optionally restart your app. The updater will only wait for 60 seconds before giving up. member.name: T:Velopack.UpdateOptions
member.summary: Options to customise the behaviour of .

member.name: P:Velopack.UpdateOptions.AllowVersionDowngrade
member.summary: Allows UpdateManager to update to a version that's lower than the current version (i.e. downgrading). This could happen if a release has bugs and was retracted from the release feed, or if you're using to switch channels to another channel where the latest version on that channel is lower than the current version.

member.name: P:Velopack.UpdateOptions.ExplicitChannel
member.summary: This option should usually be left null. Overrides the default channel used to fetch updates. The default channel will be whatever channel was specified on the command line when building this release. For example, if the current release was packaged with '--channel beta', then the default channel will be 'beta'. This allows users to automatically receive updates from the same channel they installed from. This options allows you to explicitly switch channels, for example if the user wished to switch back to the 'stable' channel without having to reinstall the application.

member.name: T:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags
member.summary: Flags determining how the links with missing targets are resolved.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_ANY_MATCH
member.summary: Allow any match during resolution. Has no effect on ME/2000 or above, use the other flags instead.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_INVOKE_MSI
member.summary: Call the Microsoft Windows Installer.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NOLINKINFO
member.summary: Disable distributed link tracking. By default, distributed link tracking tracks removable media across multiple devices based on the volume name. It also uses the UNC path to track remote file systems whose drive letter has changed. Setting SLR_NOLINKINFO disables both types of tracking.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NO_UI
member.summary: Do not display a dialog box if the link cannot be resolved. When SLR_NO_UI is set, a time-out value that specifies the maximum amount of time to be spent resolving the link can be specified in milliseconds. The function returns if the link cannot be resolved within the time-out duration. If the timeout is not set, the time-out duration will be set to the default value of 3,000 milliseconds (3 seconds).

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NO_UI_WITH_MSG_PUMP
member.summary: Not documented in SDK. Assume same as SLR_NO_UI but intended for applications without a hWnd.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NOUPDATE
member.summary: Do not update the link information.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NOSEARCH
member.summary: Do not execute the search heuristics.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_NOTRACK
member.summary: Do not use distributed link tracking.

member.name: F:Velopack.Windows.ShellLink.EShellLinkResolveFlags.SLR_UPDATE
member.summary: If the link object has changed, update its path and list of identifiers. If SLR_UPDATE is set, you do not need to call IPersistFile::IsDirty to determine whether or not the link object has changed.

member.name: T:NCode.ReparsePoints.LinkType
member.summary: Represents the type of reparse point such as a hard link, junction (aka soft link), or symbolic link.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.LinkType.Unknown
member.summary: Represents an unknown reparse point type.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.LinkType.HardLink
member.summary: Represents a file hard link.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.LinkType.Junction
member.summary: Represents a directory junction (aka soft link).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.LinkType.Symbolic
member.summary: Represents a symbolic link to either a file or folder.
member.remarks: In order to create symbolic links, the current user must either be an administrator running with elevated privileges or a non-admin user that has the SeCreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege right in local security policy.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.MaximumAllowed
member.summary: The MAXIMUM_ALLOWED access type is generally used with the AccessCheck() function to determine whether a security descriptor grants a specified set of access rights to the client identified by an access token. Typically, server applications use this function to check access to a private object. Note that MAXIMUM_ALLOWED cannot be used in an ACE (see access control entries).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.Delete
member.summary: The right to delete the object.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ReadControl
member.summary: The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor, not including the information in the system access control list (SACL).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.WriteDac
member.summary: The right to modify the discretionary access control list (DACL) in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.WriteOwner
member.summary: The right to change the owner in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.Synchronize
member.summary: The right to use the object for synchronization. This enables a thread to wait until the object is in the signaled state. Some object types do not support this access right.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.StandardRightsRead
member.summary: Currently defined to equal READ_CONTROL.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.StandardRightsWrite
member.summary: Currently defined to equal READ_CONTROL.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.StandardRightsExecute
member.summary: Currently defined to equal READ_CONTROL.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.StandardRightsRequired
member.summary: Combines DELETE, READ_CONTROL, WRITE_DAC, and WRITE_OWNER access.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.StandardRightsAll
member.summary: Combines DELETE, READ_CONTROL, WRITE_DAC, WRITE_OWNER, and SYNCHRONIZE access.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.GenericExecute
member.summary: Execute access.

member.summary: Write access.

member.summary: Read access.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.GenericAll
member.summary: All possible access rights.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileReadData
member.summary: For a file object, the right to read the corresponding file data. For a directory object, the right to read the corresponding directory data.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileListDirectory
member.summary: For a directory, the right to list the contents of the directory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileWriteData
member.summary: For a file object, the right to write data to the file. For a directory object, the right to create a file in the directory (FILE_ADD_FILE).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileAddFile
member.summary: For a directory, the right to create a file in the directory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileAppendData
member.summary: For a file object, the right to append data to the file. (For local files, write operations will not overwrite existing data if this flag is specified without FILE_WRITE_DATA.) For a directory object, the right to create a subdirectory (FILE_ADD_SUBDIRECTORY).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileAddSubdirectory
member.summary: For a directory, the right to create a subdirectory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileCreatePipeInstance
member.summary: For a named pipe, the right to create a pipe.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileReadExtendedAttributes
member.summary: The right to read extended file attributes.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileWriteExtendedAttributes
member.summary: The right to write extended file attributes.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileExecute
member.summary: For a native code file, the right to execute the file. This access right given to scripts may cause the script to be executable, depending on the script interpreter.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileTraverse
member.summary: For a directory, the right to traverse the directory. By default, users are assigned the BYPASS_TRAVERSE_CHECKING privilege, which ignores the FILE_TRAVERSE access right. See the remarks in File Security and Access Rights for more information.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileDeleteChild
member.summary: For a directory, the right to delete a directory and all the files it contains, including read-only files.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileReadAttributes
member.summary: The right to read file attributes.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.FileWriteAttributes
member.summary: The right to write file attributes.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadTerminate
member.summary: Required to terminate a thread using TerminateThread.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadSuspendResume
member.summary: Required to suspend or resume a thread (see SuspendThread and ResumeThread).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadGetContext
member.summary: Required to read the context of a thread using GetThreadContext.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadSetContext
member.summary: Required to write the context of a thread using SetThreadContext.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadQueryInformation
member.summary: Required to read certain information from the thread object, such as the exit code (see GetExitCodeThread).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadSetThreadToken
member.summary: Required to set the impersonation token for a thread using SetThreadToken.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadImpersonate
member.summary: Required to use a thread's security information directly without calling it by using a communication mechanism that provides impersonation services.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ThreadDirectImpersonation
member.summary: Required for a server thread that impersonates a client.

member.summary: All possible access rights for a thread object.

member.summary: Required to read memory in a process using ReadProcessMemory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ProcessVmWrite
member.summary: Required to write to memory in a process using WriteProcessMemory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ProcessDupHandle
member.summary: Required to duplicate a handle using DuplicateHandle.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ProcessCreateProcess
member.summary: Required to create a process.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ProcessSetQuota
member.summary: Required to set memory limits using SetProcessWorkingSetSize.

member.summary: Required to set certain information about a process, such as its priority class (see SetPriorityClass).

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.ProcessQueryInformation
member.summary: Required to retrieve certain information about a process, such as its token, exit code, and priority class (see OpenProcessToken).

member.summary: All possible access rights for a process object.

member.summary: Required to attach a primary token to a process. The SE_ASSIGNPRIMARYTOKEN_NAME privilege is also required to accomplish this task.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenDuplicate
member.summary: Required to duplicate an access token.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenImpersonate
member.summary: Required to attach an impersonation access token to a process.

member.summary: Required to query an access token.

member.summary: Required to query the source of an access token.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenAdjustPrivileges
member.summary: Required to enable or disable the privileges in an access token.

member.summary: Required to adjust the attributes of the groups in an access token.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenAdjustDefault
member.summary: Required to change the default owner, primary group, or DACL of an access token.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenAdjustSessionid

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.AccessRights.TokenAllAccess
member.summary: Combines all possible access rights for a token.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileShareMode.None
member.summary: Prevents other processes from opening a file or device if they request delete, read, or write access.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileShareMode.FileShareRead
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request read access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request read access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for read access, the function fails.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileShareMode.FileShareWrite
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request write access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request write access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for write access or has a file mapping with write access, the function fails.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileShareMode.FileShareDelete
member.summary: Enables subsequent open operations on a file or device to request delete access. Otherwise, other processes cannot open the file or device if they request delete access. If this flag is not specified, but the file or device has been opened for delete access, the function fails. Note Delete access allows both delete and rename operations.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileCreationDisposition.CreateNew
member.summary: Creates a new file, only if it does not already exist. If the specified file exists, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_EXISTS (80). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path to a writable location, a new file is created.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileCreationDisposition.CreateAlways
member.summary: Creates a new file, always. If the specified file exists and is writable, the function overwrites the file, the function succeeds, and last-error code is set to ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS (183). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path, a new file is created, the function succeeds, and the last-error code is set to zero. For more information, see the Remarks section of this topic.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileCreationDisposition.OpenExisting
member.summary: Opens a file or device, only if it exists. If the specified file or device does not exist, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND (2). For more information about devices, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileCreationDisposition.OpenAlways
member.summary: Opens a file, always. If the specified file exists, the function succeeds and the last-error code is set to ERROR_ALREADY_EXISTS (183). If the specified file does not exist and is a valid path to a writable location, the function creates a file and the last-error code is set to zero.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileCreationDisposition.TruncateExisting
member.summary: Opens a file and truncates it so that its size is zero bytes, only if it exists. If the specified file does not exist, the function fails and the last-error code is set to ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND (2). The calling process must open the file with the GENERIC_WRITE bit set as part of the dwDesiredAccess parameter.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeReadonly
member.summary: A file that is read-only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it. This attribute is not honored on directories. For more information, see You cannot view or change the Read-only or the System attributes of folders in Windows Server 2003, in Windows XP, in Windows Vista or in Windows 7.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeHidden
member.summary: The file or directory is hidden. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeSystem
member.summary: A file or directory that the operating system uses a part of, or uses exclusively.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeDirectory
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeArchive
member.summary: A file or directory that is an archive file or directory. Applications typically use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeDevice
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeNormal
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only when used alone.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeTemporary
member.summary: A file that is being used for temporary storage. File systems avoid writing data back to mass storage if sufficient cache memory is available, because typically, an application deletes a temporary file after the handle is closed. In that scenario, the system can entirely avoid writing the data. Otherwise, the data is written after the handle is closed.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeSparseFile
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeReparsePoint
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeCompressed
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed. For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeOffline
member.summary: The data of a file is not immediately available. This attribute indicates that file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeNotContentIndexed
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeEncrypted
member.summary: A file or directory that is encrypted. For a file, all data streams in the file are encrypted. For a directory, encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeIntegrityStream
member.summary: The directory or user data stream is configured with integrity (only supported on ReFS volumes). It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. The integrity setting persists with the file if it's renamed. If a file is copied the destination file will have integrity set if either the source file or destination directory have integrity set. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeVirtual
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileAttributeNoScrubData
member.summary: The user data stream not to be read by the background data integrity scanner (AKA scrubber). When set on a directory it only provides inheritance. This flag is only supported on Storage Spaces and ReFS volumes. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagFirstPipeInstance
member.summary: If you attempt to create multiple instances of a pipe with this flag, creation of the first instance succeeds, but creation of the next instance fails with ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED. Windows 2000: This flag is not supported until Windows 2000 SP2 and Windows XP.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagOpenNoRecall
member.summary: The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage. This flag is for use by remote storage systems.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagPosixSemantics
member.summary: Access will occur according to POSIX rules. This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagOpenReparsePoint
member.summary: Normal reparse point processing will not occur; CreateFile will attempt to open the reparse point. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational. This flag cannot be used with the CREATE_ALWAYS flag. If the file is not a reparse point, then this flag is ignored. For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagSessionAware
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with session awareness. If this flag is not specified, then per-session devices (such as a redirected USB device) cannot be opened by processes running in session 0. This flag has no effect for callers not in session 0. This flag is supported only on server editions of Windows. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, and Windows Server 2003: This flag is not supported before Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagBackupSemantics
member.summary: The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation. The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges. For more information, see Changing Privileges in a Token. You must set this flag to obtain a handle to a directory. A directory handle can be passed to some functions instead of a file handle. For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagDeleteOnClose
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles. If there are existing open handles to a file, the call fails unless they were all opened with the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode. Subsequent open requests for the file fail, unless the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode is specified.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagSequentialScan
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag should not be used if read-behind (that is, reverse scans) will be used. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING. For more information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagRandomAccess
member.summary: Access is intended to be random. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching. This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING. For more information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagNoBuffering
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes. This flag does not affect hard disk caching or memory mapped files. There are strict requirements for successfully working with files opened with CreateFile using the FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING flag, for details see File Buffering.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagOverlapped
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O. When subsequent I/O operations are completed on this handle, the event specified in the OVERLAPPED structure will be set to the signaled state. If this flag is specified, the file can be used for simultaneous read and write operations. If this flag is not specified, then I/O operations are serialized, even if the calls to the read and write functions specify an OVERLAPPED structure. For information about considerations when using a file handle created with this flag, see the Synchronous and Asynchronous I/O Handles section of this topic.

member.name: F:NCode.ReparsePoints.Win32.FileAttributeFlags.FileFlagWriteThrough
member.summary: Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk. For additional information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.summary: Contains the of a reparse point.

member.name: P:NCode.ReparsePoints.ReparseLink.Target

The target for the junction.
